sect2.title: Introduction to RP-PPPoE
sect2.para: The Roaring Penguin PPPoE package contains both a client and a server component that works with the client. The client allows you to connect to large networks that use the PPPoE protocol, common among ADSL providers. The server component runs alongside the client, allowing you to configure other clients that send out a configuration request.

sect3.title: Configuration Information
sect3.para: To configure RP-PPPoE after installation, you should run the adsl-setup script.

When configuring your connection, you will need to have your ISP's nameserver information available, as well as your username and password. You will also be asked whether to configure a dial-on-demand or a constant connection. If your service provider does not charge by the minute, it is usually good to have a bootscript handle the connection for you. You can, of course, choose not to install the following script, and start your connection manually with the adsl-start script.

sect2.title: Contents
sect2.para: The RP-PPPoE package contains adsl-setup, adsl-start, adsl-status, adsl-stop, pppoe, pppoe-relay, pppoe-server and pppoe-sniff.

sect3.title: adsl-setup
sect3.para: A script for configuring the client. Configuration is then stored in /etc/ppp/pppoe.conf.

sect3.title: adsl-start
sect3.para: adsl-start starts the client using the options specified in /etc/ppp/pppoe.conf.

sect3.title: adsl-status
sect3.para: adsl-status displays the status of the ADSL connection.

sect3.title: pppoe
sect3.para: This is the client itself. Generally it should not be started on its own.

sect3.title: pppoe-relay
sect3.para: pppoe-relay starts the server relay agent.

sect3.title: pppoe-sniff
sect3.para: A small network sniffer designed to assist in setting PPPOE_EXTRA settings.
